awd_titl_txt: ANES FACE-to-FACE:  The American National Election Studies 2018-2021
awd_abstract_narration:
Since the 2016 election, Americans have found themselves in a period of remarkable uncertainty and change. Some worry about threats to the nation's democracy while others are concerned that the U.S. president is unfairly targeted by the media and "witch hunt" investigations. What do Americans make of all this and how do they want to go forward? The American National Election Studies (ANES) surveys are an essential tool for answering such questions. Understanding the preferences of its citizens is the hallmark of a healthy, functioning democracy, and since 1948 the ANES has been the gold standard for measuring the opinions of the public and a leading resource in understanding voting behavior in the United States. The upcoming presidential election in 2020 is shaping up to be a defining moment in American history. Trust in democratic institutions has been declining at an alarming rate among the American public. Challenges, as well as defenses, of those institutions are coming from many directions. New and existing questions on the ANES survey will allow researchers to understand the sources of growing American discontent, explain misunderstandings between elected officials the public, and identify opportunities for bridging the country?s political and social divisions in the future.

Understanding the preferences of citizens is the hallmark of a healthy, functioning democracy, and the American National Election Studies (ANES) time series has been the gold standard for gauging and assessing the connection between public opinion and voting behavior in the U.S.  We propose to conduct the 2020 face-to-face ANES surveys, the most comprehensive and careful study of how Americans evaluate their government, form opinions about major issues of the day, participate in politics, and choose which candidates to support, and thereby extend a time series that dates back to 1948. Specifically, we propose to collect data in 2020 on a national probability sample of respondents in two waves of in-person interviews (before and after the election). The content and design of these surveys will be informed by two major pilot surveys and a number of small-scale pilots. In an era where response rates for phone surveys have dipped below 10 percent and where most online surveys still face daunting issues with respect to representativeness, the ANES survey offers reliable measurement of social, economic, and political attitudes in the context of American elections. The negativity and polarization of our political environment make the need for non-partisan, scientifically-valid survey research more pressing than ever. This is what ANES offers, while also providing unparalleled time series data that puts the nature of our current politics into appropriate historical context.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The mission of the American National Election Studies (ANES) is to help researchers, policymakers, and citizens themselves assess the vitality of our democratic process and understand better the priorities, judgments, hopes, and fears that shape the people?s choices on Election Day.

In 2020, over 155 million Americans voted in the presidential election. Why did they vote while others chose not to cast a ballot? What led them to choose one candidate over the other? How did Americans see the issues facing the country, and what policies did they want the next president to pursue?

The ANES aims to provide researchers with the data for answering these and many related questions. It has been conducting high quality surveys of the American electorate since 1948. The centerpiece of the current project was the largest ever ANES presidential survey, in which over 8,200 Americans were interviewed. Americans shared hours of their time over the course of two interviews, before and after the election, to answer questions about their values, opinions, priorities, concerns, and political activities.

The 2020 survey included a rare opportunity to reinterview a large number of people (over 2,800) who had also participated in the 2016 presidential survey. This ?panel? component of the study provides researchers with a powerful tool for studying who changed, solidified, or persisted in their views over the course of four years.

The project carried out several other national surveys between 2018 and 2020. These included three pilot surveys designed to test new questions and gauge public sentiment. Results from the pilot surveys informed the content of the presidential survey. A separate two-wave survey collected data on the political views and activities of over 5,000 citizens, with the aim of better understanding the role of social media in the political life of Americans. Finally, the project included a special collaboration between ANES and the General Social Survey (GSS). The GSS has tracked Americans? views on a broad range of social issues over the past five decades. In 2020, the ANES reinterviewed a subset of over 1,100 GSS respondents, opening a new frontier by enabling researchers to connect individuals? responses across the two projects.

Three distinctive features of the ANES project are its high-quality data collection, the breadth of its data, and its provision as a public good.

To ensure measurement quality, the project?s questions undergo extensive piloting and pre-testing, as well as vetting by a national advisory board of experts. It also invests considerable effort in training interviewers and recruiting participants. Through careful planning, months of hard work, and the resources provided by the grant, the ANES achieves an interview rate that is as much as 100 times greater than most news polls or other research surveys. As a result, researchers and polling organizations use the ANES data as a benchmark to evaluate and calibrate their own data.

The broad scope of ANES surveys yields an especially rich resource for researchers. Some questions have been asked for decades, allowing researchers to track short- and long-term changes in public opinion. Many other questions are new, responding to unique issues of the current election, recent developments in American society, and the latest insights from researchers. In 2020, the presidential survey included nearly 800 questions. The survey has long asked about evaluations of the candidates and government, voting decisions, political participation, the economy, partisanship, ideology, values, attitudes toward salient public figures and groups, and opinions on policy issues (e.g., healthcare, defense, taxes, crime, abortion, the environment, immigration).  The 2020 survey included new items on the coronavirus pandemic, democratic norms, election integrity, rural Americans, policing and protests, social media, and many more topics.

The ANES is a public good. The investigators do not use project funding to analyze and report their own conclusions about the election. Instead, the project?s core mission is to produce the data and make them available to the public. The results of the 2020 ANES study will be borne out in reports, papers, and books for years to come. The project maintains a website where users may download data, access detailed documentation on how each survey was conducted, and use tools for learning more about ANES data. There have already been nearly 20,000 downloads of the 2020 data files by researchers, students, and other interested individuals. The online bibliography of sources discussing past and present ANES data includes over 8,300 citations. The 2020 study also included a major redesign of our most popular resource (over a quarter million pageviews): The Guide to Public Opinion and Electoral Behavior. The Guide, which allows users to visualize our data, now features over twice as many trends and new tools for breaking trends down by specific groups in the population.
